svg.text: This model simulates the car and pedestrian traffic at a 4-way intersection. The car lights function according to the dynamically changed green, red and yellow durations, until a pedestrian arrives at any pedestrian light and presses the request button. The Berkeley policy is to serve the pedestrian immediately. The Manhattan policy, on the contrary, completely ignores pedestrian requests. This model features heterogeneous multi-modeling. Models of computation, such as DE (discrete-event), ERG (event relationship graph), Wireless, SDF (synchronous dataflow) and FSM (finite state machine), are used at different levels of the model hierarchy for maximum design flexibility. Another highlight is the use of model transformation with ERG controllers. Specifically, PeriodController is a component that changes the car and pedestrian arrival rates dynamically according to the intersection specification. DurationController monitors the number of waiting cars and the number of waiting pedestrians, and increases or decreases the green durations if the two numbers become too far apart.

property.name: text
property.value: (Set this parameter to BerkeleyPolicy.xml for a different request policy.)

svg.text: Christopher Brooks, Thomas Huining Feng, Edward A. Lee
(A demo of the LMATL Naomi project)

property.name: actions
property.value: IncreaseNS = (Intersection.CarCountN - Intersection.PedCountN) + (Intersection.CarCountS - Intersection.PedCountS) > Threshold; DecreaseNS = (Intersection.CarCountN - Intersection.PedCountN) + (Intersection.CarCountS - Intersection.PedCountS) < -Threshold; IncreaseEW = (Intersection.CarCountE - Intersection.PedCountE) + (Intersection.CarCountW - Intersection.PedCountW) > Threshold; DecreaseEW = (Intersection.CarCountE - Intersection.PedCountE) + (Intersection.CarCountW - Intersection.PedCountW) < -Threshold
